metadata.title: Renal Dialysis and Exercise
anatomical location body part affected: Kidneys/renal nephrons (i.e., glomeruli, tubules) and renal blood vessels; cardiovascular system with multiple comorbidities
description: Renal dialysis is a common treatment for patients with chronic kidney disease (pwCKD). Dialysis sessions are typically 3 to 4 hours in duration and administered 3 times a week(1)
Most pwCKD receiving renal dialysis are sedentary, have reduced physical functioning in activities of daily living (ADLs) as well as low cardiorespiratory endurance fitness(2,3,18,42)

Functional decline in pwCKD likely begins before renal dialysis treatment due to anemia, muscle wasting, general weakness, and physical inactivity.(3) Exercise prehabilitation (i.e., exercise training in the early stages of chronic kidney failure before starting dialysis) might prevent the decline in physical functioning and reduced physical activity seen in pwCKD receiving dialysis(51)
Comorbidities (e.g., cardiovascular disease [CVD], malnutrition, mental depression) also often contribute to disability in ADLs and reduced health-related  quality of life (HRQoL) in pwCKD(4,5)
Chronic fatigue and lethargy can further debilitate physical functioning and vitality in pwCKD(12)
Frailty and slow gait speed are especially common in older pwCKD(6,34,51)
Daily renal dialysis without exercise training does not improve physical functioning in pwCKD(7)

In contrast, moderately strong evidence supports aerobic exercise training during (intradialysis) or between dialysis sessions for improving peak oxygen uptake (VO 2peak), muscular strength, daily physical functioning, and HRQoL(34,35,43,52,53)

Resistance exercise training during dialysis treatments also appears safe and effective for improving strength, physical functioning, and quality of life,(8,9,10) as well as for reversing skeletal muscle wasting(11)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patient with CKD and reduced physical function: referral specifically for exercise program before, between, or during renal dialysis sessions

Other concerns –Sedentary lifestyle(42) –Muscle atrophy/weakness –Low age-related  VO 2peak and aerobic work capacity as indicated by exercise testing(13) –Chronic state of fatigue –Slow gait speed –Frailty in elderly patients(51) –Reduced cognitive function(36) Causes, Pathophysiology, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Stop any therapeutic activity or exercise and notify physician if patient reports the onset of symptoms associated with cardiac insufficiency (e.g., angina, inappropriate shortness of breath, dizziness)

Even in the absence of exertion-related  symptom limitations, exercise testing on a treadmill or cycle ergometer should progress very gradually and terminated when the patient expresses voluntary fatigue or other predetermined endpoints specific for the patient are reached(18)

potential causes of reduced physical fun: Prolonged illness with extended physical inactivity, leading to–Muscle disuse, atrophy, and weakness–Poor aerobic functional endurance

Anemia (i.e., low hematocrit/hemoglobin levels) resulting from diminished kidney production of erythropoietin and othercomorbidities that cause kidney failure (e.g., CVD, hypertension and diabetes mellitus)
Uremic myopathy may impair muscle O 2 extraction, as indicated by reduced arteriovenous O 2 difference duringexercise(14)

Reduced maximal-achievable  heart rate (HRpeak) despite hard or maximal exertion on incremental exercise testing.Maximal-achievable cardiac output is reduced even though cardiac stroke volume during exercise may be normal forage(7,14,15)–If in stage 5 of CKD (kidney failure), functional capacity may be only 60-70%  of age-matched  controls(18)
pathophysiology of reduced physical func: CKD that requires dialysis indicates severely impaired renal function (i.e., decreased glomerular filtration rate) with theaccumulation of nitrogenous toxins (e.g., urea, creatinine) in the blood (i.e.,azotemia)

Symptoms of uremia, such as nausea, muscle wasting, dependent edema, shortness of breath, and weakness, contribute tophysical disabilities. These changes are associated with chronic lethargy and fatigue, which promote physical inactivity andgeneral deconditioning

Potential pathophysiological consequences of CKD that may also contribute to reduced physical functioning(17)–Anemia: reduces arterial O 2 content and O 2 delivery to muscle during exercise–Peripheral neuropathy–Uremic myopathy may reduce O 2 oxygen extraction in muscle and contribute to reduced arteriovenous O 2 differenceduring exercise–Metabolic (lactic) acidosis–Autonomic dysfunction: reduced maximal-achievable  HRpeak, with reduced peak cardiac output during exercise

The reduced VO 2peak and functional aerobic work capacity of pwCKD is associated with low peak cardiac output andarteriovenous O 2 difference during maximal exercise.(7,14,15,18)(Author’s note: Although this finding is attributed toautonomic dysfunction, muscle weakness could also explain failure to achieve a maximal cardiac response)
risk factors for ckd: Traditional CVD risk factors, especially smoking and obesity(41)
Dietary habits that promote weight gain, diabetes, or hyperlipidemia
Abuse of alcohol or illegal substances
Poor adherence to medical advice regarding risk factors that contribute to sedentary living

overall contraindications precautions: The capacity to tolerate vigorous exercise is typically very low in sedentary pwCKD due to aerobic deconditioning and both chronic central fatigue (malaise or lethargy) and peripheral (muscle) weakness or fatigue. Patients may also experience muscle pain during exercise.(17) Initial or start-up workloads during either physical testing or therapeutic exercise should, therefore, feel “light” or “easy” to allow the patient warm-up  time before any “hard” physical activity.(18) Monitor vital signs and pain to ensure an appropriate adjustment to exercise

Postpone treatment and notify physician if a patient presents with recent onset of the following signs and symptoms of acute illness: Unusual/atypical fatigue for patient Fever Malaise Flu-like  symptoms (e.g., chills, headache, dizziness, muscle aches) Pulmonary crackles/rales Increased nausea Diarrhea

Stop physical activity/exercise therapy and notify physician in case of(18,19) dizziness or lightheadedness chest pain resting systolic blood pressure (BP) over 200 mmHg resting diastolic BP over 110 mmHg erratic, fluctuating, or inappropriate BP response  severe headache –Severe headache, neck pain and vomiting after routine dialysis were symptoms experienced by a patient who was diagnosed with a spontaneous nontraumatic, nonaneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage without any cerebrovascular malformation(50) pProlonged fatigue after exercise
Contact sports should always be avoided to protect the patient from trauma
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

course of treatment.medical management: Document the patient’s regimen for renal dialysis,site of dialysis port, and any other ongoing treatments (e.g., for coronary artery disease, heart failure, hypertension, diabetes, neurological disease, or osteoporosis)
surgical management: Surgical management: Document any operative procedures that may restrict the type/mode of exercise training
course of treatment.medications: CKD patients are often prescribed cardiac medications (e.g., beta blockers, antihypertensives) that may affect exercise HR or BP. Document all medications and confirm that they are being taken
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests:  The laboratory workup may include
Electrocardiogram (ECG)  taken at rest and in some cases during an exercise test
Biomarkers of impaired renal function (e.g., decreased serum albumin, increased white blood cell count, increased serum calcium, increased urinary urea, creatinine, potassium, phosphate, and calcium)
Blood glucose (a high percentage of pwCKD have diabetes)(41)
Hematocrit, hemoglobin, and red blood cell count (low readings are common but not specific for CKD)
Exercise testing under medication supervision and may involve functional tests rather than traditional graded exercise test. See Special Tests  below
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of herbal, behavioral, or other alternative therapies and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has previously received exercise therapy and, if so, what specific program

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document reported symptoms at rest and any additional symptoms during physical activity
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: If present, document number of wakings/nightDocument the use of supplemental oxygen or the need for ventilator support
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate ability to exercise and/ or symptoms that may indicate referral to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__  -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any prior exercise prescription or exercise therapy for chronic conditions?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Document any history of heart disease, hypertension, stroke, diabetes, or peripheral vascular disease
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of all prescribed and over-the-counter  medications and herbal remedies. If applicable, was there any use of illegal drugs?
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask about symptoms related to physical exertion

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient work or participate in fitness activities? What does the patient’s occupation involve? Is the patient a smoker?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: If applicableAsk about family situation, employment status and working conditions that may increase stress/anxiety. Ask about number of floors and stairs in home environment and any symptoms experienced while using steps

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Determine height, weight, and body mass index (BMI). Is the patient overweight or underweight?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Is an assistive device or wheelchair being used for general mobility or ADLs? Are any adaptive devices being used? If so, are they in good condition and being used properly?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance. Administer Functional Reach Test or Berg Balance Scale (BBS), if indicated. Ensure that exercise equipment selected for training (e.g., treadmill, elliptical trainer) can be safely used without risk for falls
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulses in upper and lower extremities
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess gross movement during transfers and functional tasks using the upper extremities (e.g., reaching, pulling, pushing, holding) and lower extremities (e.g., steps, squatting, kneeling, kicking).The Timed Up and Go (TUG) test can be used to assess functional mobility
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait, including usual speed, synchrony of limb movements, and posture, to ensure ambulatory function is satisfactory for a walking exercise program. Use 10-meter  walk test (10-mWT)  to assess gait speed. Maximal gait speed has been shown to correlate directly with renal function (glomerular filtration rate) (i.e., faster gait speed indicated better renal function).(13) Slow gait speed is common in pwCKD and may identify those at risk for disability(33) –Authors of a cohort study (n = 14 pwCKD receiving hemodialysis) found that thinking tasks while walking (i.e., “dual-tasking”)  decreased walking speed to less than 1 m/sec and altered spatiotemporal gait pattern. Dual tasking while walking could increase risk for falls(37)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Scan strength in functional tasks (e.g., hand grip, pushing, pulling, sit-up,  squatting). Assess strength in muscle groups targeted for exercise training with manual muscle testing (MMT), dynamometry, or weights
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Screen for functional ROM in all extremities to clear for prescribed exercisesAssess deep tendon reflexesScan dermatomes for normal sensation
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –Patients without contraindications referred specifically for aerobic exercise training may be able to undergo a submaximal, symptom-limited  graded exercise test in compliance with medical guidelines. Assess HR, BP, Borg’s rating of perceived exertion (RPE) responses, and for adverse signs/symptoms while conducting the test on a treadmill or cycle ergometer(16,17,18)  –Sedentary pwCKD typically have very low aerobic work tolerance. The initial workload of an exercise test protocol used to evaluate physical functioning should, therefore, feel “light” or “easy,” on Borg’s scale and subsequent workloads should progress the patient’s exertion gradually.(7,13,14,15,16,17) In this population, traditional exercise tests may not prove to be as valuable; functional tests may be more appropriate(18) –VO2peak can be measured directly in a cardiopulmonary exercise testing laboratory or estimated from standard protocols that use a treadmill or cycle ergometer(17) –Most pwCKD have a blunted HR response to progressive incremental exercise (i.e., the maximal-achievable  HRpeak on exercise testing may fall below the age-predicted level)(7,14,15,18) –The 6MWTcanalso be used to assess physical functioning in pwCKD. For example, authors of a study (n = 32 pwCKD) in the United States found that 6MWT performance correlated significantly with VO 2peak measured during maximal or symptom-limited  treadmill exercise(13) –HRQoL can be assessed using the Health Status Questionnaire Short Form (physical functioning scale and physical composite scale) (SF-36)

contraindications precautions: Systolic BP exceeds 260 mm Hg or diastolic BP exceeds 115 mm Hg
Systolic BP fails to rise more than 20 mmHg with progressive exertion
Systolic BP falls unexpectedly more than 10 mmHg with continuing exercise
Exertional symptoms such as chest discomfort, lightheadedness, or dyspnea suggest cardiac insufficiency
Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment regarding the use of modalities
Exercise may change fluid requirements, especially if perspiring heavily. Changes to fluid intake should be coordinated with physician or dietitian
other: Because of the heterogeneity of comorbidities in CKD, not all patients are suitable candidates for exercise training. Those with exercise intolerance due to muscle pain, weakness, or fatigue at low workloads are less likely to improve their physical functioning with exercise(8,17,23,24,35,36)
Tailor the exercise prescription to fit each patient’s measured functional ability, symptoms, and HR, BP, and RPE responses to exercise testing
Ensure close supervision and instruction during the initial exercise training sessions
Monitor BP on a regular basis during exercise. According to standard exercise guidelines,(17,18,19) exercise testing or exercise training should be terminated if
Resting BP higher than 180/110 mmHg is an absolute contraindication and BP higher than 160/100 mmHg is a relative contraindication to starting a resistance exercise session(18)
To prevent an exaggerated BP response to exercise, provide the patient with a thorough orientation to using the prescribed exercise equipment and with adequate warm-up  time

Although general guidelines for weight-lifting  exercise are not available specifically for pwCKD, clinical studies have shown that resistance exercise training may be well-tolerated,  safe, and improve strength, physical functioning, and HRQoL(8,9,10,11)
Resistive exercise training may help reverse skeletal muscle wasting in pwCKD(11)

Extend the cool-down  period and avoid having the patient stop suddenly and stand still after exercise because this prevents the lower-extremity  muscles from pumping, possibly causing a precipitous fall in systolic BP due to venous pooling and increasing risk of orthostatic hypotension with syncope
Clinicians should follow the exercise guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician
Electrotherapeutic and physical modalities are indicated only when prescribed by the referring physician for a coexisting musculoskeletal condition
Hydration issues for patients on fluid restriction

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: CKD requiring hemodialysis/poor physical functioning due to reduced aerobic capacity and muscle strength; physical inactivity contributing to reduced ability in ADLs and to increased risk of CVD comorbidities. Prescribed exercise training may improve cardiovascular fitness, muscle strength, physical functioning, uremia-specific measures, and HRQoL while reducing the risk of atherosclerosis CVD (hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, heart failure, arrhythmias), anemia, osteoporosis, diabetes mellitus, electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic syndrome, neuromuscular irritability
prognosis: Authors of a 2006 systematic review of 39 studies (n = 1,371,990 non-dialysis-dependent  pwCKD) found that the risk of all-cause  and CVD mortality increases exponentially with decreasing renal function(20)
Authors of an epidemiologic study (n = 4,011 pwCKD) in the United States found that increased physical activity was associated with reduced risk of rapid decline in kidney function(21)
Exercise training either during dialysis or between dialysis sessions may have beneficial effects on HRQoL in patients with CKD(9,22,34)

Authors of a retrospective cohort study (n = 102) in Canada found that patients who participated in a 6-month  outpatient intradialytic cycling exercise program had decreased hospitalization incidence rate ratio (0.48) and length of hospital stay (3.1 vs. 7.8 days) compared to patients not in the program(44)

Authors of a randomized controlled pilot trial (n = 70 pwCKD) in Tasmania, Australia found no significant improvements in 6MWT or self-reported  physical functioning at 6 months follow-up  in the group who trained 3 times per week on a cycle ergometer during dialysis compared to the group who walked at home to achieve the same amount of weekly exercise or to the controls who received usual care and did not exercise(23)

Authors of a randomized controlled trial (RCT, n = 296 pwCKD on dialysis) in Italy found that at 6-months  follow-up,  the walking exercise group significantly improved in the 6MWT (328 m to 367 m) but the usual-activity  control group (321 m to 324 m) did not(53)
Lack of improvement in self-reported  or assessed physical functioning after adequate exercise training may indicate a poor prognosis, similar to patients with chronic heart failure(25)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Physician for management of worsening symptoms related to renal failure; clinical exercise physiologist for cardiopulmonary exercise testing and measurement of VO 2peak; nutritionist for dietary management and advice on weight management and fluid restriction; occupational therapist for limited instrumental ADLs; psychiatrist/ psychologist for stress-anxiety  disorder or depression
other considerations: Reduced physical activity in pwCKDis often associated with significant malnutrition or mental depression(4,5)

Exercise training may have positive benefits on factors other than physical functioning that are important clinical issues in renal dialysis patients, such as CVD risk profile, oxidative stress, BP, and inflammation(26)

The author of a 2009 review concluded that professional kidney organizations and nephrology practitioners at large are slow to adopt recommendations for physical activity and hesitate to encourage physical activity as part of routine medical care for pwCKD(27)

Specific guidelines for home exercise are lacking. In most cases, pwCKD should be counseled to be as physically active as their health permits on at least 3 days of the week and exercise at an exertion level that is easily tolerated without undue fatigue for 30 minutes per day(8,9,10,11,18,27)
treatment summary: The American College of Sports Medicine makes the following exercise recommendations regarding frequency,intensity, time, and type (FITT) for pwCKD:(18) –Frequency – Aerobic exercise 3 to 5 days per week, resistance exercise 2 to 3 days per week –Intensity – Moderate intensity aerobic exercise (40 to < 60% of HR reserve, RPE 11-13  on 6 to 20 scale); resistance exercise of 70 to 75% 1 repetition maximum –Time – 20 to 60 minutes of continuous activity; if not possible, 3 to 5 minute bouts of intermittent exercise aiming to accumulate 20-60  minutes per day; resistance training – at least 1 set of 10 to 15 repetitions; also include flexibility exercises –Type – walking, cycling, swimming for aerobic; machine or free weights for resistance exercise

Aerobic exercise training –Type of activity: Rhythmic movement with the legs (e.g., walking,(28) jogging, or cycling), arms (e.g., upper-body  cycle ergometer), or both legs and arms (e.g., elliptical trainer with arm levers) -Authors of an RCT (n = 26 pwCKD receiving hemodialysis) in Thailand found that thehome-based progressive walking program group increased their lower extremity strength significantly more than the usual-activities  group(28)  -Intradialysis cycling exercise training is safe for selected pwCKD and is associated with improved physical functioning and HRQoL(29,38,39,45,46) -Authors of a 2014 continuing education article provided recommendations for implementing an intradialytic exercise rehabilitation program based on their practical experience in the United Kingdom(45) -Authors of a 2014 systematic review of 24 studies with meta-analysis  (n = 997 pwCKD) found that intradialysis exercise was safe and suggested that a clinical guideline for nephrology practitioners should be updated on the benefits of intradialytic exercise(46) -Authors of a single-group  trial (n = 10) in the Republic of Korea found that a 12-week  program of intradialytic cycling exercise (30 minutes, 3 times per week) did not increase muscle mass or strength in knee extension, even though 6MWT, estimated VO 2peak, and HRQoL improved(47) -Authors of an RCT (n = 18) in France found that a 12-week  program of intradialytic cycling exercise (30 min, 3 times per week) improved plasma isoprostanes (markers of lipid peroxidation) and lipid profile, while improving 6MWT in the exercise group. Body composition did not change in either the exercise group or controls(48) –Intensity -The prescribed exercise training intensity should, if possible, be based on the HR, BP, and RPE responses during maximal, symptom-limited  treadmill or cycle-ergometer  testing(17); otherwise, physical performance tests like the 6MWT should be used(18) -“Light” to “somewhat hard” exertion, equaling 11 to 13 on the Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Test (6to20)(30) -The predicted HR peak based on age should not be used to prescribe target training HRs for pwCKD because their maximal-achievable  HRpeak is often reduced(7,14,15) –Duration: Intradialytic aerobic exercise training sessions are usually 30 min in duration. Physical activities may involve continuous or discontinuous exercise totaling 30 min of physical activity per day. Five hours or more per week may promote losing excess weight(18) –Frequency: 3 alternating days per week during or between dialysis(31) -If done during dialysis, exercise should be done during first half of dialysis treatment; otherwise, should be done on days not in dialysis(18)

Resistance exercise training –Muscle strengthening should be a goal of exercise therapy in the management of most pwCKD. However, the intensity of resistance exercise that is generally effective without compromising safety for most patients varies on a case to case basis similar to aerobic exercise and this emphasizes the importance of individual screening and strength testing(49) –Authors of a 2014 systematic review with meta-analysis  (n = 5 trials) found a small but significant effect of resistance exercise training on increasing muscle mass. However, the authors concluded that only 1 of 9 pwCKD on hemodialysis is likely to receive a clinically important benefit based on their findings(40) –Type of activity: Circuit training.(8,9,10,11) Weight-lifting  exercises using machines or free weights (e.g., leg press, chest press, leg extension, lat pull-down, leg curls, shoulder press, biceps curl, triceps press)(8,9,10,11) –Intensity: Low to moderate intensity.(18) Resistance training at 40-60%  of 1-RM  is used for pwCKD, as in persons with CVD(17,18,19) –Duration: 1-3 sets of 10 repetitions per exercise, taking about 30 min to complete the exercise session, depending on individual fatigue(8,9,10,11,18) –Frequency: 2-3 nonconsecutive days per week(8,9,10,11,18,19)
Combined aerobic and resistance exercise training that follows the above general guidelines also appears to be safe and effective exercise for pwCKD(24,45)

Aquatic exercise between dialysis sessions may increase strength and physical performance. Authors of a small cohort study (n = 20 pwCKD on dialysis) in Poland found that isokinetic knee strength and physical fitness improved after a 3-month  interdialysis aquatic training program(54) .
